solution:
Hubble's law implies

$$\mathbf{v}_1 = H_0 \, \mathbf{r}_1$$

for the galaxy at $\mathbf{r}_1$.  Subtracting this from the general law, we have

$$\mathbf{v}_i - \mathbf{v}_1 = H_0 (\mathbf{r}_i - \mathbf{r}_1)$$

Now we define the distance to galaxies in a new coordinate system, in which the galaxy at $\mathbf{r}_1$ lies at the origin.  Thus, we define the transformation

$$\mathbf{r}_i' = \mathbf{r}_i - \mathbf{r}_1$$

Differentiating with respect to time, we obtain the corresponding transformation for galactic velocities:

$$\mathbf{v}_i' = \frac{\mathrm{d} \mathbf{r}_i}{\mathrm{d} t} = \mathbf{v}_i - \mathbf{v}_1$$

Substituting, we may therefore write, in the new coordinate system,

$$\mathbf{v}_i' = H_0 \, \mathbf{r}_i'$$
statement: Hubble found that distant galaxies are receding with a velocity proportional to their distance from where we are on Earth. For the $i$th galaxy, $$\mathbf{v}_i = H_0 \, \mathbf{r}_i$$ with us at the origin. Show that this recession of the galaxies from us does not imply that we are at the center of the universe. Specifically, take the galaxy at $\mathbf{r}_1$ as a new origin and show that Hubble's law is still obeyed.
author: Arfken & Weber
